ui.bodyBullet: In this module, learn how using a Customer-Driven Parts Sales Process can directly influence customer satisfaction, loyalty and sales.
First, it’s helpful to understand why customers don’t complete a purchase and what they expect from the purchase experience.
Why don’t customers buy?
• The Parts Advisor fails to ask for the sale. The customer may be ready to buy, but needs to be asked for the sale
• The customer doesn’t trust the Parts Advisor and feels they are trying to sell them something they don’t need
• The customer doesn’t recognize the value for the price. The Parts Advisor hasn’t presented the features and benefits that meet the customer’s needs
• Inconvenience such as having to wait for a part, to wait to be served, to wait on hold on the phone, or to search for the Parts Department
How do you get customers to buy? What do they expect?

ui.bodyImage: Customer at parts counter with Parts Advisor

ui.bodyBullet: Customers expect exceptional service. That means…
They want to be treated as a valued customer, to know that you care about helping them and that you can be trusted.
They want a relationship that is built on respect for them as a person with unique needs.
They want you to be responsive to their questions and concerns.
And they want to be treated fairly.
Having a formal, customer-driven parts sales process to follow can help provide the level of service customers expect and help close more sales.
The process in this course has four steps:
• Initiate the Customer Relationship
• Identify the Need
• Present the Solution
• Ask for the Sale

ui.bodyNote: Download the Customer-Driven Parts Sales Process resource listed on the Learning Center Assignments page for this course.

ui.bodyBullet: • Answer the call within three rings
• Smile
• Give your name and department
• Ask for customer’s name to make a personal connection and how you may help
• Ask for permission to put a customer on hold and explain why
• Return to call within 30 seconds
• Welcome customer promptly and sincerely
• Make eye contact and smile
• Give customer your full attention
• If on a call when customer arrives, acknowledge him or her and indicate you will be right with them
• Present professional image through posture and body language
• Observe the customer’s body language, be sensitive to it, and adjust your own appropriately
• The dealership is one team, not separate departments
• Providing good customer service to Sales and Service co-workers improves everyone’s bottom line
• Greet promptly and treat them as you would an external customer
• Make sure they have the information they need to give customers price quotes
• Partner with Sales Consultants to promote accessory sales so they know they can come to you for any information they need
• With internet customers, the relationship is electronic, so written words communicate your and your dealership’s image
• Acknowledge customer and respond within 20 minutes of receiving an inquiry. Write in a friendly yet professional style
• Provide the information requested so it is easily understood
• Review your response for grammar or spelling errors
• Include dealership name, phone number, and employee contact information

ui.bodyBullet: Customers may not be aware of what they really need when they contact you. They may need:
• Additional Parts
• A different part
• To bring the vehicle into the dealership for service
It’s your job to listen and identify your customer’s true need. How do you do that?
• Listen closely to the customer, and gather information to identify the real need
• Mopar products are engineered for specific vehicles, so first get the VIN from the customer
• Engage the customer in conversation by asking open-ended questions. You will get more information than those requiring yes or no answers
Let’s learn how a Parts Advisor gathers information from his customer.
Parts Advisor: “Okay, Mr. Adams, there are two types of spark plugs available for your 2010 PT Cruiser. We have standard and platinum-tipped. Which type would you like?”
Identify additional selling opportunities.
• Are there related parts that the customer will need to make a proper repair?
• Is there a kit with all the parts needed that will save the customer time and money?
• Are there seasonal parts or dealership promotions that the customer might consider?
Get the customer everything he or she needs the first time to build trust and provide good customer service.
Let’s learn how that would work with our customer.
Customer: “Why would I want platinum-tipped spark plugs?”

Parts Advisor: “Well, they’ll last 160,000 kilometers, so you probably won’t have to change them again, which will save you money in the long run. Can I help you with any other maintenance work you’re doing?”
The Parts Advisor asked an open-ended question to find out more information about what the customer might actually need.
He responded to the customer’s question by presenting a value-added explanation and inquiring about additional selling opportunities.

ui.bodyBullet: • Presenting the solution is where your product knowledge and experience pay off
• You have begun to build a relationship with your customer, establishing mutual trust and respect
• You understand the customer’s needs and have identified any additional selling opportunities
• Now you can effectively make recommendations, highlighting the benefits and value of what you’re selling
Key points to remember when presenting solutions to customers:
• Be positive
• Stay focused on the solution and how you can help rather than what is not available

Parts Advisor: “These are very sharp wheels you’ve selected for your Chrysler 300, Ms. Cramer. We’ve made sure they’re specifically designed for your car. We don’t have them in stock right now, but I can have them here for you tomorrow – and I can take you over to our Service Department to arrange to install them.”
The Parts Advisor speaks with an enthusiastic tone.
He turns the situation into a positive experience by assuring he can solve the problem quickly.
• Present the solution to your customer’s initial request before asking about additional parts
• Most customers won’t listen to a recommendation before the original request has been addressed
• Explain the benefits and value of your recommendation, to build customer satisfaction and loyalty

Parts Advisor: “So, Mr. Adams, you’ve decided on platinum-tipped spark plugs for your PT Cruiser. That’s a good choice. You’re getting original equipment parts of the highest quality, reliability and durability. You’ll be saving money over the life of your car with these. Is there anything else you need? We have a maintenance kit that includes an air filter and fuel filter, designed specifically for your car, which will save you even more money.”
The Parts Advisor addressed the customer’s initial request by confirming his choice and explaining the benefits. He then asked the customer about additional parts and included a benefit.
• Avoid using technical jargon and complicated explanations
• Take advantage of the tools and resources you have, such as StarParts

Parts Advisor: “As you can see on StarParts, Mr. Kemp, your vehicle actually has rear disc brakes rather than drums as you originally thought. You’ll need brake pads instead of brake shoes. I have the part number for those right here. Have you also inspected the rotors?”
The Parts Advisor keeps his explanation simple.
• Once you have presented the right solution, provide your customer with the cost
• If the part or accessory will be installed, be prepared to quote an installed price

Parts Advisor: “Ms. Cramer, these wheels are a great value. They’re cast aluminum, they won’t corrode, and they’ll stay bright for the life of the car. The price for all four is $1,124. As I said, I can have them here for you tomorrow. Let me take you to our Service Department to schedule an appointment to have them installed.”
The Parts Advisor gave the customer more benefits to enhance the value of her selection, then quoted her a price and arranged for installation.

ui.bodyBullet: • Asking for the sale can be the most challenging step for some Parts Advisors
• Done well, you not only make a sale, but gain a loyal customer and even more sales
• Before you ask for the sale, make sure you have the customer’s commitment to buy
• Demonstrate how your solution meets the customer’s need
• The customer will stop listening if he or she doesn’t see the value in what you’re selling
• Make the benefits of what you’re selling real and attractive. For example, with accessories, show a customer how the part will make his or her vehicle stand out
• Once you have the customer’s commitment, ask for the sale. People who are asked will buy more often than those who are not asked
• Be prepared to counter any objections and to ask for the sale again
• There are a number of ways to ask for the sale
• Ask questions throughout your presentation to confirm the customer’s readiness to buy
• Speak as if the customer has agreed to the order
• Offer customers a choice as if they have agreed
• Summarize customer’s needs and how your solution supports them

ui.bodyBullet: • No matter how confidently you ask for the sale, you will occasionally experience customer objections
• Objections are opportunities. The customer is interested, but needs more information

ui.bodyNote: Download the Overcoming Customer Objections resource listed on the Learning Center Assignments page for this course.

ui.bodyBullet: The three most common customer objections are:
Price
“That seems awfully high for a set of brake pads. I think I’ll check some other stores.”
Value
“Why should I buy this water pump from you? I can get one just as good down the street.”
Availability
“You don’t have the headlamp I need in stock? I took time out of my lunch hour to come here and waited 15 minutes to find this out?”
The key to overcoming customer objections is to anticipate them and be prepared to respond.

ui.bodyNote: Download the Overcoming Customer Objections resource listed on the Learning Center Assignments page for this course.

ui.bodyBullet: When your customer raises an objection, treat it with respect and hear them out.
• Be an active listener. Hear the customer’s words, and try to understand the motivations and feelings. Don’t interrupt
• Ask questions to understand the objection, and then paraphrase the objection back to the customer
• Respond to the objection with the benefits and value of what you’re recommending. Confirm that you’ve resolved the objection
• Ask for the sale. You may have to repeat this more than once

Parts Advisor: “I understand that you’re concerned about the price of the brake pads. I can tell you that our price is reasonable, because we check our competition regularly. So, can I write that up for you?”

Value
Customer: “Why should I buy this water pump from you? I can get one just as good down the street.”

Parts Advisor: “You want a water pump for your 2011 Durango, and I understand you believe an aftermarket water pump is as good as an original equipment part. Some of my customers have had the same concern. May I explain the difference to you so you recognize that we can offer you much better quality and reliability at a competitive price?”
Read how our Parts Advisor addresses each of the customer objections.
Availability
Customer: “You don’t have the headlamp I need in stock? I took time out of my lunch hour to come here and waited 15 minutes to find this out?”

Parts Advisor: “I’m so sorry for the inconvenience. I understand that your time is valuable. Is your need immediate or can you wait a day or two? Well, I’m glad you’re able to wait. I can have a new headlamp here for you tomorrow. If you would prefer to have our Service Department install it, we’ll take care of that at no charge to make up for the inconvenience.”
